The system should check the data bit value accuracy of the interface data to ensure it meets the accuracy requirements, and correctly process and output results when the data bit value accuracy is less than or greater than the required accuracy.

The system should set safety values and compare them with the normal values of interface data when no fault occurs. When the difference between the safety value and the normal value under non-fault conditions is too large, the system should be able to detect and properly handle it, preventing abnormal situations from occurring.

requirement: The system should support adjusting the throttle valve opening during climb phase 1 by fine-tuning the throttle valve, with the limit range set to [-15%, 0%].
safety_requirements: The system should limit the rate of change of the throttle valve opening within a reasonable range, ensure that the upper and lower slope limits are set appropriately, and clearly handle data that exceeds this range.
The system shall check whether the throttle position value acquired by the sensor is within the specified range (-15% to 0%) and report a sensor fault when the acquired value exceeds the range.

The system should ensure that the sequence and timing of controlling the throttle valve opening are coordinated with the hardware, that control conditions are complete and consistent, and that safety issues caused by control logic errors are avoided.

The system should check the control resolution results of the throttle valve opening, analyze the correctness of handling under different conditions (normal values, abnormal values, boundary values, maximum and minimum values, etc.), and ensure the safety and reliability of the system.

The system should have a reasonable fault detection logic, using detection methods that do not affect the normal operation of the equipment, ensuring timely identification and handling of faults to prevent safety accidents.

requirement: The brake command issued by the remote control has the highest priority. Regardless of the current control mode, when a "brake" command is received, the aircraft will superimpose the full brake value onto the left and right brake control outputs respectively, then perform limit checking. The full brake value can be remotely set, with a default value of 80%.
safety_requirements: The system should immediately add the full brake command to the left and right brake control outputs upon receiving the remote brake command, and perform limit checking to ensure the aircraft responds to the brake command in a timely manner.

The system should monitor for timeouts on brake commands sent remotely, and if no confirmation response is received within the specified time limit, the system should automatically trigger a warning mechanism and implement corresponding safety measures.

The system should check and verify the control resolution process of brake commands under different states and operational phases to ensure that brake commands are properly processed and executed in all circumstances.

The system should check and verify the calculated brake control values to ensure they are within the normal range. If the calculated values exceed the normal range, the system should automatically handle the overrun condition and trigger the warning mechanism.

The system shall adopt explicit handling strategies, such as truncation or outputting data based on safe values, when output data exceed limits, ensuring that output data remains within safe ranges and causes no harm to the aircraft.

The system shall automatically perform status checks and recovery after a power failure restart, ensuring correct status recovery and the ability to continue normal operation. If the status recovery fails, the system shall automatically trigger an alarm mechanism and implement corresponding safety measures.

requirement: When receiving the "release brake" command, braking is performed according to the calculated left and right brake amounts (i.e., without superimposing the full brake amount). At this time, if the calculated brake amount δb is 0, both left and right brakes take the corresponding brake preset values.
safety_requirements: When the system receives the "release brake" command, it should check the current operation phase and status to ensure braking is performed according to the calculated left and right brake amounts without superimposing the full brake amount. When the calculated brake amount δb is 0, both left and right brakes shall adopt the corresponding brake preset values.

The system should perform real-time checks on the calculated brake amount δb, analyze whether it is a normal value, abnormal value, boundary value or extreme maximum/minimum value, and trigger a warning mechanism in case of anomalies.

After a power failure and subsequent restart of the software, the system should check its current status and ensure correct state recovery. If the state is not recovered or is incorrectly recovered, an error handling mechanism should be triggered.
The system should monitor the control solution process, analyze whether a timeout occurs, and trigger the error handling mechanism upon timeout to ensure the correctness of function processing.

The system should check the values of continuous output data with different redundancies, analyze the consistency of the values of two or more redundant output data, and trigger an error handling mechanism when the values are inconsistent, ensuring the correctness of function implementation.

requirement: When receiving a vehicle command or a brake release command, the left and right brake control amounts are taken as the left and right ground inspection brake amounts, respectively.
safety_requirements: When the system receives a vehicle command or a brake release command, it should check the values of the left and right brake control quantities to ensure they respectively take the left and right ground inspection brake amounts, and verify the correctness of functional implementation when two or more redundancies are in different states.

The system should perform consistency checks on the same input data values received by different redundancies, ensuring that the same input data values received by two or more redundancies are consistent; otherwise, it shall trigger an exception handling mechanism.

During the control solution process, the system should verify the correctness of the control solution results, ensuring they are normal values, abnormal values, boundary values, or extreme maximum/minimum values, and handle them accordingly based on different states and operational phases.

The system should check functional inputs, analyze the correctness of functional processing in scenarios such as "unconsidered operational phases" or "unconsidered operational states," and trigger warning mechanisms or adjust function implementation when necessary.

The system shall ensure the correctness of functional control resolution processes under different states and operational phases, taking into account the influence of operational phases and states, and performing corresponding control resolutions and treatments according to the specific circumstances.

requirement: Upon receiving the flight control pre-shutdown command, set the left and right brake control values to 0, i.e., clear the left and right brake preset values.
safety_requirements: After the system receives the flight control pre-shutdown command, it should immediately set the left and right brake control outputs to 0, and verify the correctness of this operation to ensure that no state recovery errors occur due to software power-off restart.
The system shall perform real-time monitoring of the brake control clearance operation, and when the control quantity is not properly cleared, trigger a warning mechanism and record an error log.

When the system performs brake control value clearing operations, it should take into account the current operating phase and status to ensure the correctness and safety of the operation. Functional processing errors must not occur due to ignoring the operating phase or status.

The system should be equipped with a reasonable timeout detection mechanism to promptly identify and address issues when hardware status fails to meet control requirements for an extended period, preventing the system from entering an unsafe state.

The system should avoid division by zero when processing data for the brake control value clearing operation, ensuring the correctness and safety of data processing, and preventing system crashes or erroneous results.

requirement: Brake command processing is performed only during ground standby, takeoff roll, and landing roll phases.
safety_requirements: When the system receives a brake command, it should first determine whether the current state is in ground waiting, takeoff roll, or landing roll phase. If not in these states, the brake command shall not be executed.
The system should perform a reasonableness check on the processing of brake commands, taking into account the equipment status, to avoid issuing dangerous control commands or actions.

The system should be equipped with a timeout detection mechanism to handle situations where the hardware status fails to meet control requirements for an extended period. For example, if the braking action is not completed within the specified time, an alarm or error handling should be triggered.

The system should specify requirements for handling responses to incorrect or invalid operations, for example, when an operator mistakenly sends a brake command, the system should be able to identify and reject the execution of that command.

The system should evaluate the validity of operator inputs and refrain from responding to commands that are inconsistent with the current scenario or state. For example, brake commands should not be executed during mid-flight.

The system should specify response handling for operations that do not comply with the operating procedures, for example, when an operator attempts to issue a brake command in an illegal state, the system should provide an error message or warning.

requirement: When retracting the landing gear, set both left and right brake quantities to 50%; when extending the landing gear, set both left and right brake quantities to 100%. At the end of landing gear retraction, set both left and right brake quantities to 0%; at the end of landing gear extension, set both left and right brake quantities to the preset value.
safety_requirements: When retracting the landing gear, the system should check whether the brake quantities on both sides are set to 50%, and when deploying the landing gear, it should check whether the brake quantities on both sides are set to 100% to ensure correct brake quantity settings.

The system should check whether the brake quantities of both left and right sides are set to 0% at the end of landing gear retraction, and check whether the brake quantities of both sides are set to the preset value at the end of landing gear extension, to ensure correct recovery of the brake quantities.

The system shall monitor the state transitions of retracting and extending the landing gear. When a state transition occurs, it shall check whether the brake setting is correct and trigger a warning mechanism in case of anomalies.

After a power failure and subsequent restart of the system software, it should check whether the current state has been correctly restored, particularly whether the brake settings have returned to their preset values, and trigger a warning mechanism if the state is not restored or incorrectly restored.
The system should check the brake settings under different operating conditions, analyze whether the brake settings are correct in each state, and trigger a warning mechanism in case of anomalies.

requirement: When an aircraft is returning and landing, if the conditions for safe landing are not met and the landing continues, it may affect the safety of the landing. To enhance the safety of aircraft landing, a go-around function is provided to enable the aircraft to adjust its flight status and land again.
safety_requirements: When the aircraft returns and lands, the system should monitor the safe landing conditions in real time and automatically trigger the go-around function when the conditions are not met, ensuring the safety of the aircraft.

The system should have a comprehensive fault recovery mechanism to ensure that it can quickly return to normal operation in case of a failure during the go-around process and continue to perform the go-around function after recovery.

The system should be capable of detecting state transitions and adjusting the execution of the go-around function according to the post-transition state, ensuring the correctness of the go-around function in different states.
The system should check the status entry conditions in real time and activate the go-around function when the conditions are met, ensuring the aircraft can land safely.

The system should be capable of detecting changes in the conditions for function execution and interrupt the go-around function when the conditions are not met, resuming the go-around function only after the conditions are satisfied again to ensure aircraft safety.

The system should have a clear state transition mechanism to ensure that the go-around function can be correctly executed when transitioning between different states, and that the state and function remain consistent.

requirement: After the aircraft enters the glide path in autonomous or manual correction mode, if it switches to remote control, and then switches back to autonomous control mode when the flight altitude is higher than the decision height (40m), the aircraft will automatically perform a go-around using a soft transition method from remote control to autonomous control.
safety_requirements: After an aircraft enters the glide path in autonomous or manual correction mode, if it switches to remote control, when the flight altitude is higher than the decision height (40m), if it reverts to autonomous control mode again, during the automatic go-around process, it shall ensure the correct execution of the soft transition method from remote control to autonomous control, to prevent abnormal aircraft status.

During the transition from autonomous or manual correction mode to remote control operation after the aircraft enters the glide path, the system should be able to detect flight altitude and correctly trigger the transition to autonomous control mode when above the decision height (40m), ensuring aircraft safety.

When an aircraft automatically initiates a go-around in autonomous control mode, it should be capable of monitoring flight status in real time and triggering an early warning mechanism upon detecting anomalies, to ensure flight safety.

The system should be capable of correctly executing the soft transition from remote control to autonomous mode after the aircraft enters autonomous control mode, preventing abnormal aircraft conditions and ensuring flight safety.

During the transition from autonomous or manual correction mode to remote control operation after entering the glide path, the system shall be capable of correctly processing functional inputs, taking into account the operational phase and status, to ensure correct function handling and flight safety.

requirement:
When both of the following conditions 1) and 2) are met, execute the go-around command:  
1) The flight altitude is higher than the decision height (40m). If the control mode is not remote control, it must also meet the requirement of having entered the glide path.  
2) Received flight switch command: "Go-around".
safety_requirements: The system should be able to correctly execute the go-around command upon receiving the flight switch command "Go-Around" and when the flight altitude is above the decision height (40m). If the control mode is not remote control, it should also check whether the aircraft has entered the glide state.
When executing a go-around command, the system should ensure consistency between the current flight status and the target status to prevent safety risks caused by status inconsistency.
The system should be able to detect the reception status of the flight switch command "Go Around," and trigger a warning mechanism or take corrective actions when the command is not received or lost.

When executing a go-around command, the system should be capable of monitoring flight altitude and decision height in real time to ensure the go-around operation is performed under the correct conditions.
The system should have a fault recovery mechanism to restore normal operation in case of a failure during the execution of a go-around command, ensuring flight safety.

When executing a go-around command, the system should be able to prevent safety risks caused by hardware status failing to meet control requirements for an extended period, for example, by including a timeout detection mechanism to handle such situations.

requirement: If the aircraft is in autonomous control mode, directly control the aircraft to perform a go-around; if the aircraft is not in autonomous control mode, automatically switch to autonomous control mode first, then control the aircraft to perform a go-around. The smoothing method is the same as that used during mode transitions.
safety_requirements: When the system is in autonomous control mode, it should ensure the correctness and safety of the aircraft's go-around control, including checking factors such as the aircraft's current state, target state, and environmental conditions.

When the aircraft is not in autonomous control mode, the system should automatically switch to autonomous control mode and ensure the safety and correctness of the mode transition, including checking the preconditions and postconditions for the mode transition.

The system should have a softening function identical to the softening method during mode transitions, ensuring a smooth switch to autonomous control mode and execution of go-around control in case of anomalies.

After a software power failure and restart, the system should be able to check and recover to the correct state, including verifying the correctness of state execution and interface data communication.
The system should have a clear fault recovery mechanism, including the identification of fault types, causes, and recovery strategies, to ensure rapid return to normal operation.

The system should be capable of analyzing and processing functional inputs under different states and working phases, including checking factors such as working phases and operating statuses, to ensure the correctness and safety of functional processing.

requirement: When DH > 10m, transition to the descent phase, reset the airspeed control integrator to zero, and set the softening time limit to 2 seconds.
safety_requirements: When the system is at DH > 10m, before transitioning to the descent phase, it should check whether the current status meets the transition conditions to ensure the correctness of entering the descent phase.

When the system transitions to the descent phase, the airspeed control integrator should be properly reset to zero, and a softening time limit of 2 seconds should be set to ensure smooth transition into the descent phase.
The system should monitor the duration of the descending phase; if the duration is less than the specified time, a warning mechanism should be triggered to ensure task completion.

The system should perform real-time checks on the control calculation results. If the calculation results are abnormal values, boundary values, or extreme maximum or minimum values, a warning mechanism should be triggered to ensure control correctness.
The system should be equipped with an overload switching time timeout detection mechanism. If the switching time is too long, it should trigger an early warning mechanism to ensure state correctness.

When the system experiences a power failure and restart during state execution, it should correctly recover the state. If the state is not recovered or is erroneously recovered, an early warning mechanism should be triggered to ensure the correctness of the state.

The system should implement timeout detection for critical controls or actions. If the hardware status fails to meet control requirements for an extended period, a warning mechanism should be triggered to ensure control correctness.

requirement: The system should support discretization calculations in both longitudinal and lateral directions.
safety_requirements: The system should perform real-time monitoring of parameters for longitudinal and lateral discretization calculations, ensure their rate of change remains within reasonable limits, and apply predefined handling strategies to data that exceeds these limits.
The system should check the discrete value ranges of interface data to ensure that data bit values are within the valid range and can correctly handle each enumeration value.

The system should check the discrete value ranges of interface data to ensure that the data values between two consecutive cycles do not experience abrupt changes, and can properly handle such situations if they occur.

The system should ensure that the sequence and timing of controls are coordinated with the hardware, control conditions are complete and consistent, to avoid safety issues caused by sequence or timing errors.

The system should check the discrete value ranges of interface data to ensure that the data bit values are not undefined abnormal values outside the valid range, and can properly handle such situations to prevent system failures or safety hazards.

The system should be capable of detecting and responding to anomalies during longitudinal and lateral discretization calculations, including data failure, calculation overflow, etc., and should be able to automatically recover or prompt the user for intervention.

requirement: Push the throttle to 100% position, transition the flight phase to climb segment 2, control the aircraft longitudinally to climb to the final approach altitude, and laterally to intercept the final approach course from the current point. Once reaching the final approach altitude and leveling off, the aircraft will exit the go-around status and set the flaps to 15°. Then re-enter the final approach course and land again.
safety_requirements: The system shall check the correctness of functional inputs during the process of executing the throttle push to 100% position, transitioning the flight phase to climb segment 2, longitudinally controlling the aircraft to climb to the final approach altitude, and laterally controlling the aircraft to intercept the final approach course from the current point, ensuring that the current operational phase and status are considered to avoid functional processing errors caused by neglecting the operational phase or status.

After the system executes the altitude hold at the five-side approach height and the aircraft exits the go-around mode with flaps set to 15°, it should verify the correctness of the control computation results, ensuring proper handling of functional processing when the computation results are normal values, abnormal values, boundary values, or extreme maximum/minimum values.

During the execution of multi-function serial processes, the system should check the fulfillment of pre-function execution conditions to ensure the correctness of multi-function processing under situations where pre-function execution conditions are fulfilled, change from fulfilled to unfulfilled, unfulfilled, or change from unfulfilled to fulfilled during subsequent function execution.

After the system restarts due to power failure or the watchdog reset mechanism is triggered, it should verify the correctness of state execution, ensuring proper state execution in cases such as states not being restored or errors occurring during recovery after restart, and it must be able to return to normal operation.

The system should monitor the control solution results of the functions in real time during function execution, ensuring the accuracy and consistency of the solution results, and trigger a warning mechanism in case of anomalies.

requirement: The setting of a starting point is not allowed during the go-around process, but changing the landing direction is permitted.
safety_requirements: During the go-around process, the system should prohibit setting a new starting point, only allow changing the landing direction, and perform real-time monitoring and recording of such operations.

The system should have a fault recovery mechanism to ensure that it can return to normal operation after power recovery or reset due to runaway conditions, and correctly handle changes in landing direction during the go-around process.

The system should be capable of judging the rationality of personnel operations. If an operation does not conform to the current scenario or state, the system shall not respond and shall record such events for subsequent analysis.

The control sequence and timing of the system should be coordinated with the hardware to ensure complete and consistent control conditions, thereby avoiding safety risks caused by incorrect operation sequences.

The system should specify a clear response handling mechanism for non-compliant operational procedures, including but not limited to rejecting abnormal operations, triggering alarms, and recording events, to ensure safety during the go-around process.

requirement: When the aircraft is flying at a constant altitude or in the first glide segment under autonomous or manual correction control mode, if the airspeed is judged to be continuously three times lower than a certain value (see appendix for specific value) or the pitch angle is judged to be continuously three times greater than 10 degrees, the aircraft is considered to have entered a stall condition.
safety_requirements: When the aircraft is flying at a constant altitude or in the first segment of a descent, if the airspeed is judged to be continuously less than a certain value for three consecutive times, or the pitch angle is judged to be continuously greater than 10 degrees for three consecutive times, the system should correctly identify that the aircraft has entered a stall condition and trigger the corresponding warning mechanism.

Under autonomous or manual correction control mode, the system shall monitor changes in airspeed and pitch angle in real time to ensure accurate detection and implementation of corresponding control measures when entering a stall condition.

The system should be able to correctly handle the entry conditions of a stall state, including cases where the conditions are satisfied, not satisfied, and satisfied again, ensuring the correctness of state execution and flight safety.

After a software power failure and restart, the system should be able to correctly recover the judgment and control of stalled conditions, preventing safety risks caused by incomplete or incorrect state recovery.
The system should correctly control the resolution process according to different working stages and states, ensuring correct functional handling during stall conditions and flight safety.

The system should correctly check and analyze the entry conditions and transition conditions of the stall state, ensuring the correctness of state execution and transitions, and preventing errors in state execution due to situations such as simultaneous satisfaction of conditions or condition satisfaction during state execution.

requirement: Transition to climb phase 2, elevator airspeed control, advance throttle to 100%. If the aircraft has entered glide slope 1 and stalls, initiate go-around control.
safety_requirements: When the system transitions to climb phase 2, the current aircraft status should be checked to ensure correct elevator airspeed control and throttle lever setting at 100%, and to enable proper go-around control if the aircraft enters descent phase 1 and stalls.

After power recovery or activation of the runaway reset mechanism, the system shall be able to return to normal operating conditions, ensuring the correct execution of the control logic for transitioning into climb phase 2.

After a software power failure and restart, the system should be able to correctly check and restore the current status, ensuring that the control logic for entering the climb phase 2 can be properly executed after the restart.

The system shall be capable of correctly executing the control logic for transitioning into Climb Segment 2 based on the current flight phase and status, including elevator airspeed control and advancing the throttle to 100%, and shall be able to correctly enter go-around control when the aircraft enters Descent Segment 1 and stalls.

The system should be capable of checking the control solution results for transition to climb phase 2, ensuring they are normal values, abnormal values, boundary values, or maximum/minimum values, and correctly execute the control logic based on the results.

The system should have a clear fault recovery mechanism to ensure that in the event of a fault occurring during the transition to climb phase 2, it can correctly recover to a normal operating state and execute the fault recovery mechanism.

requirement: When the airspeed is judged to have increased beyond the given speed for five consecutive times, the aircraft exits the stall condition and proceeds to the next flight phase (either climb phase 2 or altitude hold phase) based on the current altitude deviation.
safety_requirements: The system shall check the aircraft's current status and altitude deviation when it consecutively determines five times that the airspeed has increased beyond the given speed, ensuring transition to the correct phase (climb phase 2 or constant altitude phase) and continuing flight.

The system shall perform real-time checks on state transition conditions, analyze the correctness of state transitions under conditions such as "not set, always satisfied, and never satisfied," to ensure the accuracy and safety of aircraft state transitions.

When the system transitions between states, it should check the values of functional interface data, analyze the correctness of outputs in cases such as "value changes or value range changes", and ensure the correctness and safety of state transitions.

The system should check multiple state transition conditions, analyze the correctness of state transitions when multiple conditions are met simultaneously, and ensure the accuracy and safety of aircraft state transitions.

During the execution of system states, the state entry conditions should be checked in real time, and the correctness of state execution under situations such as "condition satisfied, condition not satisfied, condition satisfied again" during execution should be analyzed, ensuring the accuracy and safety of aircraft state execution.

requirement:
The aileron deflection command needs to undergo allocation of control surface commands before the rudder deflection angles command calculated by the control law is output to the actuator. 

(Note: Based on the requirement, "rudder deflection command" has been translated as "control surface commands" in this context while keeping with technical terminology and flow of the sentence.)
safety_requirements: When the system allocates rudder deflection commands, it should ensure that the control sequence and timing are coordinated with the hardware, and that control conditions are complete and consistent to avoid control errors.

The system should check functional inputs according to different operating statuses and phases, analyze the correctness of functional processing in cases such as "unconsidered operation phase" or "unconsidered operation status", and ensure the accuracy of rudder deflection command distribution.

The system should be equipped with a timeout detection mechanism to handle situations where the hardware status fails to meet control requirements for an extended period, preventing system hang-up or loss of control.
The system should ensure the timing of outputting control states meets the scenario requirements, avoiding errors caused by outputting control commands too early or too late.

The system should monitor the hardware status and determine its compliance with control requirements. When a mismatch is detected, an early warning mechanism or corrective action should be triggered to ensure system safety and reliability.

When the system allocates rudder deflection commands, it should take into account the characteristics and limitations of aileron deflection commands to ensure that the allocated commands are reasonable and effective, avoiding damage to the system.

requirement: The efficiency of aileron upward deflection and aileron downward deflection is different, with lower efficiency during upward deflection and higher efficiency during downward deflection. By allocating control surface deflection commands through different distribution coefficients, the goal is to achieve consistent control effectiveness.
safety_requirements: The system should ensure consistent control performance by distributing rudder deflection commands when the efficiency of aileron up and down deflections is different, and consider the influence of operational phase and status in the calculation of distribution coefficients.

When the system allocates rudder deflection commands, it should verify the correctness of functional inputs, analyze the correctness of functional processing without considering the operation phase or status, and ensure that the calculation results of allocation coefficients are accurate under different statuses and operation phases.

The system should perform real-time checks on the results of rudder deflection command allocation, analyze the correctness of functional processing in cases where the control solution result is a normal value, abnormal value, boundary value, or extreme maximum/minimum value, and trigger a warning mechanism in case of abnormalities.

When the system allocates rudder deflection commands, it should ensure that the control sequence and timing are coordinated with the hardware, that control conditions are complete and consistent, and that error handling is performed when control conditions are incomplete or inconsistent.

The system should analyze the correctness of function implementation, considering cases where two or more redundancies are in different states when the efficiency of aileron deflection differs between upward and downward movement, and ensure that the results of control surface command allocation are accurate under different operating conditions.

requirement: If the aileron deflection command δx > 0, then the left aileron deflection command δxL = k1 δx, and the right aileron deflection command δxR = k2.
safety_requirements: The system shall monitor the aileron deflection command δx in real time, and when δx > 0, ensure that the left aileron deflection command δxL and right aileron deflection command δxR are calculated according to the ratio of k1 and k2, with the calculation result within the allowable error range.

The system should check the data bit value accuracy of the interface data to ensure that the data bit value accuracy meets the accuracy requirements. When the accuracy is below the required level, the system should correctly process and output the rudder deflection angle command.

The system shall be capable of detecting faults in one or multiple redundancies and maintaining the correctness of functions in such cases, ensuring accurate and reliable output of aileron deflection commands.

The system should perform boundary checks on the control solution results to ensure that the calculated values of aileron deflection commands δxL and δxR are accurate under normal, abnormal, boundary, maximum, and minimum conditions, and can correctly handle functional outputs in all cases.
The system should be able to correctly output rudder angle commands even when the data bit value accuracy exceeds the precision requirements, and ensure the validity and reliability of the commands.

The system should be able to handle the operating states of different redundancies, particularly maintaining correct and stable functionality when two or more redundancies are in different states, ensuring accurate output of aileron deflection commands.

requirement: If the aileron deflection command δx < 0, then the left aileron deflection command δxL = k2 δx, and the right aileron deflection command δxR = k1 δx, where k1 is the upward deflection distribution coefficient and k2 is the downward deflection distribution coefficient.
safety_requirements: The system should check the rate of change of the aileron deflection command δx to ensure it is within a reasonable range and have a clear handling strategy for data that exceeds this range.

The system should check the calculated results of the left and right aileron deflection commands δxL and δxR, analyze their correctness under normal values, abnormal values, boundary values, and extreme maximum/minimum values, ensuring they conform to the expected control logic.

The system should check the precision of interface data values to ensure they meet precision requirements. When precision is insufficient, the system should have appropriate measures to ensure output correctness.

The system should be capable of handling aileron deflection commands under different operating conditions, including situations where two or more redundancies are in different states, ensuring correct functionality implementation and safety.

The system should monitor the aileron deflection command δx in real time. When δx < 0, the system should correctly calculate the left and right aileron deflection commands δxL and δxR, ensuring they meet the specified formula and coefficient requirements, and provide an early warning mechanism in case of anomalies.

requirement: The flight control and management software shall be capable of calculating the stall speed based on the given flight weight, altitude, and flight true airspeed.
safety_requirements: The flight control and management software shall be capable of detecting and handling abnormal external factors (such as high sea states, adverse weather conditions, etc.) when calculating stall speed, and ensuring the accuracy of the calculation results.

The flight control and management software shall be capable of checking and verifying the input flight weight, altitude, and flight vacuum speed based on the current operating phase and status to ensure the accuracy of calculated stall speed.

The flight control and management software should be capable of real-time monitoring and analysis of the calculated stall speed, and when abnormal values, boundary values, or extreme maximum/minimum values occur, it should trigger a warning mechanism and implement necessary corrective actions.

The flight control and management software, in the process of calculating stall speed, shall be capable of detecting and handling calculation timeouts, ensuring that calculation results are returned within the specified time, and taking necessary measures in case of timeout to ensure flight safety.

The flight control and management software should coordinate with the hardware devices to ensure the correctness of control sequence and timing, and the control conditions should be complete and consistent to avoid safety risks caused by improper control.

requirement: The system shall support the calculation of the target airspeed during climb.
safety_requirements: The system should implement a timeout determination mechanism when calculating the given airspeed during climb, to handle situations where hardware status fails to meet control requirements for an extended period, ensuring system stability and safety.

The system shall perform overspeed data checks on the output airspeed data, and when the data exceeds the preset range, a clear handling strategy shall be adopted, such as truncation or outputting according to safety values, to prevent unpredictable behavior of the system.

The sequence and timing of the system's climb control should be coordinated with the hardware, and the control conditions should be complete and consistent to ensure the correctness and safety of the system.

The system should clearly define the sensor's acquisition range (upper and lower limits). When sensor data exceeds the acquisition range, a sensor fault should be reported to prevent the system from using incorrect data for control.

The system should check the execution timing of different redundancies, analyze the correctness of function implementation in cases such as "two or more redundant executions are not synchronized," and ensure the safety and reliability of the system.

The system should perform real-time monitoring of the calculated indicated airspeed to ensure it remains within the preset range, and trigger a warning mechanism in case of anomalies to prevent the system from entering a hazardous state.

requirement: The flight control and management software should support stall speed calculations for different flap angles, particularly for a flap angle of 40°.
safety_requirements: The flight control and management software should be capable of accurately calculating the stall speed when the flap angle changes, especially when the flap is at 40°, and it should be able to automatically adapt to stall speed calculations under different flap angles.

The system should perform real-time monitoring of stall speed calculations under different flap angles. If the calculated results exceed preset thresholds or abnormal conditions occur, the system should automatically trigger a warning mechanism and prompt the pilot to take appropriate actions.

The flight control and management software shall take into account the effects of different operational phases and conditions when calculating stall speed, ensuring the accuracy and reliability of the calculation results, especially under high sea states or adverse weather conditions.

The system should be able to detect and handle faults or failures of the flap angle sensors. If one or more sensors fail, it should automatically switch to backup sensors or take other emergency measures to ensure the calculation of stall speed continues.

The flight control and management software should be capable of identifying and handling abnormal external factors (such as high sea states, adverse weather conditions, etc.), and adjusting stall speed calculation parameters according to actual conditions to ensure flight safety.

requirement: The ground waiting phase transitions to the takeoff ground segment (takeoff roll segment) after the base leg and airport pressure altitude are set and a takeoff clearance is received.
safety_requirements: Before transitioning from the ground holding phase to the takeoff ground segment, check if the final approach path and airport pressure altitude have been set, and ensure that the takeoff clearance has been received to prevent inadvertent initiation of the takeoff roll segment.

The system should monitor the transition from the ground waiting phase to the takeoff ground segment, ensure that the conditions for entering the state are met, and continuously check these conditions during the execution of the state. If the conditions are not satisfied, the takeoff roll segment should be terminated immediately.

The system should be capable of detecting and responding to abnormal external factors (such as high sea states, severe weather conditions, etc.), and making appropriate judgments and handling based on actual conditions to ensure flight safety.
The system should ensure consistency of entry and exit conditions for each mode, preventing state conflicts or incorrect transitions that could affect flight safety.

The system should perform reasonableness checks based on the equipment status when issuing control commands or actions, preventing dangerous commands or actions from being issued, to ensure flight safety.

requirement: During the takeoff roll phase, when the airspeed exceeds 30 m/s and the altitude is greater than 15 m, it transitions to the takeoff departure phase, with a softening time limit set to 2 seconds.
safety_requirements: During the transition from the takeoff roll phase to the takeoff climb phase, the system should monitor airspeed and altitude, and trigger the phase transition logic when the airspeed exceeds 30 m/s and the altitude exceeds 15 m, with a soft time limit set to 2 seconds.

The system shall perform real-time monitoring of airspeed and altitude data, and trigger a timeout judgment when exceeding the set threshold, to prevent situations where the hardware status fails to meet control requirements for an extended period.

When transitioning from the takeoff roll phase to the takeoff climb phase, the system should output the control status at a timing that meets scenario requirements, ensuring correctness and smoothness of the state transition.

The system should check the transition conditions between every pair of states in the software state space, analyze the correctness of state transitions under conditions such as "not set," "always satisfied," and "never satisfied," and ensure the rationality and effectiveness of the transition conditions.

The system should be capable of detecting and responding to abnormal external factors (such as high sea states, severe weather conditions, etc.), and making appropriate judgments and handling to ensure the safety and reliability of the system.

The sequence and timing of system control should be coordinated with the hardware, and control conditions should be complete and consistent to avoid control conflicts or errors, ensuring system stability and safety.

requirement: During the takeoff departure phase, when the flight altitude exceeds the safety height of 80m, it transitions into climb segment 1. The elevator channel adopts a method of setting integrator initial value softening, while other channels do not require softening.
safety_requirements: During the takeoff departure phase, when the flight altitude exceeds the safety altitude of 80m, the system should automatically transition to climb segment 1. The elevator channel shall adopt a method of setting initial integral values for softening, while other channels do not require softening, and ensure correctness of the control calculation process during transition to the new phase.

The system should monitor the flight altitude in real time. When the flight altitude exceeds the safety height of 80m, it should trigger the logic to switch to climb phase 1, and ensure the correct implementation of the elevator channel integrator initial value softening.

When the system transitions into Climb Segment 1, it should verify the correctness of the control solution results, ensuring they are normal values, abnormal values, boundary values, or maximum/minimum values, and perform corresponding functional processing based on the results.

The system should ensure that the sequence and timing of controls are coordinated with the hardware, control conditions are complete and consistent, to avoid incorrect functional processing due to sequence or timing errors.

When a software power failure and restart occur during system state execution, the state after restart should be checked, situations where the state fails to recover or recovers incorrectly should be analyzed, and the correctness of state execution must be ensured.

The system shall check the consistency between the task execution sequence and the specified sequence, analyze the correctness of functional processing when task execution sequences are inconsistent, and ensure that the execution order of all tasks complies with specified requirements.

requirement: During climb segment 1, start retracting the landing gear. If the landing gear is retracted, delay for 5 seconds before starting to retract the flaps. If the landing gear is still not retracted after 1 minute, directly retract the flaps to 0 degrees. If the flaps are retracted to 0 degrees, transition to climb segment 2 after a 5-second delay. If, entering climb segment 1, the flaps have not been retracted to 0 degrees within 75 seconds, directly transition to climb segment 2. The softening time limit during transition to climb segment 2 is 2 seconds.
safety_requirements: When the system starts retracting the landing gear at climb segment 1, it should check the landing gear retraction status to ensure that flap retraction begins 5 seconds after the landing gear is fully retracted. If the landing gear has not been retracted within 1 minute, the flaps should be directly retracted to 0 degrees.

During the process of retracting flaps in climb segment 1, the system should monitor the flap status retracted to 0 degrees, ensuring that after the flaps are fully retracted to 0 degrees, it delays for 5 seconds before transitioning to climb segment 2. If, after entering climb segment 1, the flaps have not been retracted to 0 degrees within the 75-second time limit, it should directly transition to climb segment 2 with correctness verification.
When the system transitions into the second climb phase, the time limit should be softened to 2 seconds to ensure the correctness and smoothness of the state transition.
After a power failure and subsequent restart, the system should check the status recovery to ensure correct status restoration and error-free functional processing.
The system should check functional inputs and control resolution processes under different states and operational phases to ensure the correctness and consistency of functional processing.

The system should analyze cases where task durations are less than the specified time during continuous duration checks for various tasks, to ensure the correctness of functional processing and compliance with time constraints.
The system should check the interface data communication status during software power failure and restart, to ensure normal interface data communication and correct output.

In the system's functional control calculation result check, it should analyze situations where the control calculation results are normal values, abnormal values, boundary values, or extreme maximum/minimum values, to ensure the correctness and robustness of functional processing.

requirement: In the climb phase 2, if the aircraft does not stall, corresponding actions are taken based on the altitude difference DH between current altitude and desired altitude: 1) When DH > 10m, switch to the descent phase, set the softening time limit to 2 seconds, and use the method of setting integrator initial value for softening in the elevator channel. 2) When -10m ≤ DH ≤ 10m, switch to the altitude holding phase, and set the softening time limit to 2 seconds.
safety_requirements: During the system's climb phase 2, the difference DH between current altitude and desired altitude should be checked to ensure timely transition to the descent phase when DH > 10m, correct transition to the constant altitude phase when -10m ≤ DH ≤ 10m, and the time limit for phase transition should be softened to 2 seconds.

The system should perform real-time monitoring on the elevator channel. When DH > 10m, the elevator channel should be softened using a method that sets the integrator initial value, ensuring the correctness and safety of the softening process.

The system should perform real-time checks on the control calculation results, analyzing whether the control calculation results are normal values, abnormal values, boundary values, maximum or minimum values, etc., to ensure the correctness and safety of functional processing.

The system should ensure that the sequence and timing of controls are coordinated with the hardware, with complete and consistent control conditions, to avoid safety issues caused by sequence or timing errors.

The system should monitor the parameter change rate to ensure it remains within a reasonable range (upper and lower slope limits), and implement a clear handling strategy for data exceeding these limits, to prevent safety issues caused by abnormal parameter change rates.

requirement: Set the initial values of the altitude hold control integrator, altitude tracking integrator, and throttle control integrator (calculate the initial value of the throttle control integrator assuming the throttle position is 100%) to perform softening, preparing for altitude hold control and altitude tracking control.
safety_requirements: When setting the initial values for the altitude control integrator, altitude tracking integrator, and throttle control integrator, the system should check whether the calculated results are within the normal range to ensure the correctness of the softening process and prevent control errors caused by abnormal or boundary values.

The system should verify that the control solution results are coordinated with the hardware, ensuring complete and consistent control conditions to avoid safety issues caused by sequence or timing errors.

The system should check whether the rate of change of parameters is within a reasonable range (upper and lower slope limits) and define handling strategies for out-of-slope data to ensure controllability and safety of parameter changes.
The system should record and retain all control operations and parameter changes in the history log for traceability and analysis, ensuring system transparency and safety.

requirement: If on the fifth leg of the traffic pattern and within the glide window, transition to Glide Segment 1; otherwise, handle according to the difference between current altitude and desired altitude (DH).
safety_requirements: When the system enters the glide slope window on the fifth leg of the traffic pattern flight, it should correctly transition to Glide Slope Segment 1, ensuring the accuracy and timeliness of the state transition.

The system should perform real-time monitoring and calculation of the difference in height (DH) between the current height and the desired height, ensuring the correctness and effectiveness of corresponding processing based on the DH value.

When the system transitions between different states, the correctness of the state transition conditions should be checked and verified to ensure the correctness and safety of switching between high-priority and low-priority functions.

The system should monitor and control the rate of parameter changes, ensuring that the rate of change remains within a reasonable range, with clear and effective data handling strategies for out-of-range slopes.

The system shall perform real-time monitoring of data bits with continuous value ranges in the interface data, analyze the differences between data values across multiple cycles, ensure the correctness and validity of outputs, and properly handle and respond when the difference in data values exceeds the specified threshold.

When the system transitions between operational states, it should check the values of functional interface data, analyze the correctness of outputs when values or value ranges change, and ensure the safety and reliability of state transitions.

requirement: When DH > 50m, switch to the descent phase, set the softening time limit to 2s, and use the method of setting integrator initial value softening for the elevator channel.
safety_requirements: The system transitions to the descent phase when DH > 50m; the softening time limit is set to 2 seconds. requirement: When DH < -50m, switch to climb phase 2, set the softening time limit to 2s, and use the method of setting integrator initial value softening for the elevator channel.
safety_requirements: When the system enters the second climb phase with DH < -50m, the softening time limit is set to 2 seconds. requirement: When the normal flag lateral control flag is changed from other modes to final approach flight, set the initial value of the altitude tracking integrator for softening; when the normal flag lateral control flag is changed from final approach flight to other modes, set the initial value of the altitude hold control integrator for softening.

requirement: Process according to the value of DH, which is the difference between current altitude and desired altitude: if -10m ≤ DH ≤ 10m, switch to the constant altitude phase, set the softening time limit to 2s, and initialize the softening process for the constant altitude control integrator, altitude tracking integrator, and throttle control integrator, preparing for constant altitude control and altitude tracking control.

requirement: Enter climb phase 2, set softening time limit to 2 seconds, and use the method of setting integrator initial value softening for the elevator channel.

requirement: During the glide phase 1, when the flight altitude is below 100m, switch to glide phase 2, reset the straight-side slip control integrator and heading control hold integrator to zero, prepare for flight control in glide phase 2, and set the soft time limit to 2 seconds.

requirement: In the glide phase 2, when the flight altitude is below 17m, it transitions to the flare phase. The elevator channel adopts a method of setting initial integral value for softening, while other channels do not require softening.
safety_requirements: When the system transitions from the glide phase to the flare phase, it should check whether the flight altitude is below 17m to ensure correct conditions and reasonable timing for transitioning into the flare phase.

requirement: During the flare segment, when the flight altitude is below 1.5m, transition to the roll correction leveling segment, and no channel softening is performed.

It must ensure that the conditions for not performing softening on each channel are satisfied, and under these conditions, the correctness of the state transition has been verified.

The system should check whether the conditions for transitioning into the roll-out phase have variation rates within reasonable ranges (upper and lower slope limits), and have a clear handling strategy for data exceeding these slope limits.

When the system enters the roll-to-level flight phase, it should check whether the state transition conditions have been set, whether they are always satisfied or cannot be satisfied, and ensure the correctness of the state transition.
